text: July 31st, 2014 - The second line in the grid of my lovely Summer Camp beer box belongs to the Yonder Bock, brewed in collaboration with Cigar City. After exiting the can, it burns with a fiery, ember red, as if fuming to be removed from its metallic place of rest. The smell is crowded with tropical fruit flavors, including pineapples, mangos and papayas. And as if rounding out the mid-century American treatment of these fruits, there is a tiny cherry note in there too, delicately placed on top of the pile of exotic, acidic sweets. The body is solid, easy to tackle, and the flavor begins light and sweet, the maraschino cherry with an introductory trumpet of bright, syrupy sugar. Then mango flavors ease in, before cutting off suddenly, leaving a pale fruit juice flavor that ebbs long into the aftertaste. Theres a lot of the South Pacific here, and I adore it - the beer for tiki-philes.

12 oz can from Beer Camp series 2014. Pours a deep copper orange color and topped by a small off white head of foam that slowly settles to a thin film and leaves scant patches of lace on the glass. The aroma shows notes of tropical fruit with mango, pineapple, and other ripe fruit to go with a sweet malt base of toasted caramel, bread, and toffee. Just a touch of citrus hop bitterness provides balance. The flavor follows and is quite sweet with the fusion of sweet caramel and toffee malts to go with the ripe tropical fruits of mango and pineapple. Some mild citrus hop bitterness tries to offer balance on the back side. Medium bodied and slick on the mouthfeel with balanced carbonation that leads to a sweet and fruity finish with some trace heat from alcohol left behind. Nice mash up of flavors but ultimately ends up too sweet for my liking.
Nice aroma and flavor of tropical fruit with a floral and piney bitterness. Nice copper color with a medium-weight palate and strong carbonation. Easy to drink.
Can 0.355l at home. Enjoyed straright from the can. Aromas and flavours: Harshness, caramel, nuts,  some fruits, chocolate, sweetness and malts.

12 oz can served in a pint glass. Pours darkish amber with medium slightly creamy white head. Aroma is boozy sweet caramel malt, with a decidedly crisp herbal, floral note on the back. Taste is rich lightly sweet caramel malt, again the potency of the malt is easily evident. Clean juicy floral notes on the back balance nicely. I know blocks are pretty minimal on the hops, but would work so well with the malt and everything else here. Pretty sure these tropical notes are not common in a bock, but a great twist on the style.

Two great brewers come together for a new take on a style, yes please. Pour is an burnt orange with a off white frothy head. Bigger alcohol masks the traditional light heller style and it has a bit of a punch that i enjoy.
Pours amber brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is malty with dried fruit. Flavor is slightly syrupy sweet with a nice bitter finish. Rich body with a nice fizz.

Sampled from a 12 oz can this beer poured a dark caramel-orange color with a medium sized creamy-fluffy orange-white head that left decent lacing. The aroma was tropical fruits - pineapple, mayo and papaya - with sweet sugar. The flavor was sweet and tangy with almost tobacco followed by tropical fruits and sugar. Medium length pineapple and mango finish. Moderately full bodied. Well done.
Golden Kupfer im Glas, klar, kein Schaum, süßlich in der Nase, Alkohol, getrocknete Früchte, Sherry, relativ leicht, süßlich fruchtig, nicht so alkoholisch im Geschmack

Ok, Im a little shocked, but I didnt really dig this. Maybe the can was too old, or maybe I wasnt really expecting the right thing from a bock, but it ended up being a mish mash of malty sweet with pungent hops. And, the hops...they were wonderful, but I didnt like it with the sweet, sweet malt. I admire the exploration of style, though.

Can at home. Great for the style. Near perfect pour- rich, deep ever-so-slightly-hazy orange with a generous white head. Malt definitely dominates and overall impression is sweet but still enjoyable. Raisins, caramel, bread and tropical notes. Not the best of the case, but decent.

Can, shared by Jookos, thx! 
Deep amber,  thick creamy off white head.  Nutty,  almonds,  sweet aroma,  raisins. Flavor has  caramel,  bready malt,  fruit cake.  Medium bodied.  Pleasant.
Can. Amber, light nitty, llight haze. Malty, slight nutty, slight herbal nose. Med bodied, quite smooth nice. Caramels, some nuttyness. Not a favourite style of mine, but ok.-- bb

Keg at the Green Dragon, PDX, 11/11/14.
Clear amber with a decent beige covering.
Nose is malt forward, toffee apple, spice, fruit rinds.
Taste comprises biscuit malt, rich toffee, dark fruit rinds, stewed prunes, orchard wood.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Ok bock.

text: [Tap] Brass colored pour with only wisps of foam left on top. Sweet and sticky aromas of caramel, residual sugars and hints of alcohol. Flavors of toffee, sweet breads, candied tropical fruits and some lemon. A nice coating mouthfeel. Low levels of carbonation. I enjoyed it. Tasting notes from 7/2014.

355 ml bottle. Canned 04.05.2014.
Pours clear copper color with a large head. Quite stuffy on the nose, thick malty and caramel up front, some resinous hops and nutty notes on the background. Very sweet toffee-syrupy flavor, caramel and malts, mild resin and some molasses. Cant really locate the Bock elements here.
5323

355ml can from Saveur-Biere

Taste is malty, earthy and stuffy with hints of fruits, caramel, toffee and syrup. Finish is sweet, syrupy and malty with some earthy notes. Not very fresh any more, feels stuffy and sweet.

35,5 cl can @ lusikka, canned 4.5.2014
Colour is something between heller and dunkler bock. Aroma has nuts, caramel and hayish malt. Feels sweet and heavy. Flavour has nuts, harsh malt, caramel, mellow grapefruit-like hops and toffee. Very American and quite far from traditional bock. Musty, sweet and heavy stuff.
Dark amber pour with an off-white head. Aroma is fruity hops, malt. Taste is smooth with fruity hops in the finish. Sweet and tasty overall. So-so lacing.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2015 Location: Draft at HopsScotch, 2/7/15


Aroma: An okay aroma of sweet malts and some fruity notes.

Appearance: Pours a dark orange-reddish, thick and frothy beige head, coating lace.

Flavor: It has a sweetish flavor as well, it feels like it is lacking in balance.

Palate: It has a pretty smooth mouthfeel that is quite creamy.

Overall Impression: 
Not my favorite beer, but Im happy to have given it a try as I thought these beers were long gone at this point.

Aroma is sugary and malty with some overtones of ripe, fleshy fruits. Orange color with a slight chill haze and a dense head of beige-colored foam. Caramel and toasted grain flavor with over-ripen pineapple and sweet citrus. Medium-full body, smooth and creamy texture, slightly chewy. This is a good beer, but I was really hoping for more of the tropical fruit to come through. Maybe its just getting a bit too old at this point since it was brewed back in May 2014? Drinks a bit thick and too heavy; the alcohol doesnt hide quietly in the background.

This was shared tasting with Strykzone oh Facebook Chat. Poured an orange amber with a big beige head and excellent retention. Light lacing. Nose of mango and pineapple. Medium body. Flavor is malty with mango and pineapple. Other flavors in there too. Can not identify. Finish is dry and bitter citrus. Quite drinkable but the odd flavors distract.
Tasty but Im not a big bock fan, particularly at these high abv. Yes tropical fruit. Medium mouthfeel, pleasant aroma.

Amber pour, big head. Extremely malt forward in both aroma and taste. Only the slightest hints of tropical fruits peeking through. Medium body. Either the bit of age this has on it did it no favours or the brewers involved went full on malt. Much prefer the rye boc they did with oskar blues.

Nice amber/kool-aid orange, with a thick beige head. Aroma is mainly maltly, not a ton of fruit outside of the mango. Taste is similar to the aroma, pretty malty with dried fruit, and apricot lingering.

Pours copper with a finger of off-white head. Aroma is bready, nutty, toffee, and fruit. Taste is malty up front, toffee and bread, then raspberry, candied tropical fruits, a bit of citrus, and booze. Low bitterness. The "fancy" hops in this beer have a hard time shining past the malt.

tap. hazy amber with a small head. fruity, sweet, malty aroma with light fruit esters. flavor is malty and very fruity with apple, pear, floral and tropical guava fruits. medium full body. really nice beer. one of the best light colored bocks i can remember in a long time!

Draft. Rich amber beer with a cream head. Light sweet malt aroma with light fruitiness. Malt and light honey flavor with light fruitiness and light earthiness.. Medium bodied. Malt and light honey linger with light fruitiness.

Sampled on 12/25/2014. This heller bock pours a deep amber color from a 12oz can. Medium sized white foamy head with decent retention and nice lacing. The aroma is fruity and sweet, tropical (mango, pineapple and coconut?) and bready. A medium bodied heller bock. The malts are caramel, fruity and sweet. The hops are herbal. Decent carbonation. Lots of flavors going on here, tropical, melon and bready. Interesting beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

December 20m 2014. Can at home, canned may 4, 2014. 
Clear amber with a creamy dense white head. Aroma is sweet malty with raisin and fruity notes, apple and some tropical fruits. Taste is medium sweet fruitcake notes, sweet malty and dried fruits, with a very light bitterness. Medium bodied, small bubble carbonation.
Une cannette 06/04/14. Une bière simple comme toutes celles de la sélection Beercamp. Houblon floral au nez, malt au miel sucré. Idem en bouche.

Pours a light copper. Head is initially two fingers, but rapidly fades away. Aroma - not getting a lot of tropical fruit - some spicy hops, a bit of malt maybe underneath. Taste - not getting the advertised tropical hop notes at all. Given the advertised taste profile, this is pretty disappointing.

Empaquetée le 06/04/14. Bronze ou cuivrée comme couleur de robe. Enfin, quelque chose comme ça. Belle mousse généreuse de son temps. Traces collées sur la paroi de me verre. Nez bien maltée avec une céréale dorge en bonbon. Généreuse portion de houblons avec son bouquet floral et ses fruits précisément tropicaux et mûrs. Sur les papilles, une base qui me rappelle la Dead Guy avec, en prime, une touche dexotisme. Corps moyen et texture huileuse. Pétillement juste. Finale qui mélange une amertume de houblons aux notes amères des céréales grillées. Un style qui ne mallume plus vraiment.

Clear copper and bronzed coloured body with a nice clear glow and a rich, two centimetre tall tan head. Aroma of alcohol, metal, malt, nuts, raisins and a touch of apples and pears. Medium-bodied; Assertive malty character with a defined nuttiness and pungent earthy character that doesnt let go - strong until the very end. Aftertaste shows some light sweetness from caramel and toffee, a bit of the raisin and earthy pungency and not too much pleasant at the end. Overall, a decent bock at best with some rather earthy and strong flavours that dont show off too well. I sampled this twelve ounce can purchased from Harris Teeter in Arlington (Pentagon Row), Virginia on 30-July-2014 for US$22,00 for the twelve pack, sampled at home in Washington, a few steps away, on 09-December-2014. This is sadly all a reputation rating - this isnt a bad beer, per se, but not good, and not worth saving nor worth searching out for, period.

12 oz can split with Huhzubendah. Pours a clear copper orange with lasting creamy white head. Aroma is sweet and tropical-leaning. Mango, papaya, and pineapple are overpowering. Flavor is same with thin syrupy body, mild carbonation and sweet caramel finish. Out of style.

Copper body with  a small white head. Sweet boozy aroma. Mango comes through with too much alcohol heat. Maibocks are already sweet, and this is too much, even cloying. I didnt particularly enjoy this one.

Fruity spicy nose, seemed unusual. Orange, dark, clear, with thick proud lacing and retention. Very dry. Similar taste with the fruit and spice dominating. Not sure how I feel other than I probably would not order again.

On tap at MacGregors Hen. Pours a clear amber/red with a large frothy off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt, toffee, nuts and a good amount of hops. Flavour of bready caramel malt, toffee, hops, nuts and a moderate bitter finish. Alcohol is hidden well. Medium bodied.

Can. Pours a clear copper orange with a large beige head. Gentle malt and a touch of yeast with some bread and fruit. Medium bodied, malty and sweet, a touch of jammy oxidization flavors. Tangy citrus and chewy floral malt into the finish. A bit of warm alcohol.

Pours out a deep amber color with a small white head. Aroma is of bready/caramel malts, light fruity hops, mild citrusy hop bitterness and some bread crusts. Taste is lots of caramel malts, bread dough, light fruity hops, a touch of bitter citrus fruit, lingering sweetness. Solid beer for a style that usually for me doesnt get much better than meh.
Grapefruit, pineapple, lots of european malt. Lush tropical fruits. Not a bad beer.
Can. Dark caramel with a dense head. Fruity and yeasty sugar. Cloying, sticky fruit.
Can thanks to sonnycheeba. Pours a nice amber with a thin layer of off white head. Taste and aroma of malts and some fruit.
On tap at Sideways in Fayetteville. Pours amber with two fingers of white head. Some malty caramel and some floral. Didnt really get the fruitiness. But overall, a nice beer.

Can poured into a shaker. Pours a clear, dark rusty orange with a solid 2+ fingers of thick! white head. Aroma is loads of tropical fruits-mango, pineapple and citrus with a decent caramel backbone. Taste is medium bitter, follows aroma. Full bodied with a creamy and slightly sticky texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Very good.
Enjoyed this one. Amber pour foamy head. Mango malt aroma. Some citrus mango little caramel and malt bread. Moderate body and carbonation. Good.

Can. Pours bright, clear orange with white head. Aroma is very fruity, tropical mangos, tangerines, grapefruit, earthy. Taste is bitter throughout, medium bodied, medium carbonation, resinous. Overall, good.

I really wanted to like this one more; however, the "tropical" notes were not quite as pronounced as I was expecting both in aroma and taste. Its still good--just not great. I wanted a bit more sweetness and smoothness but the hops tend to magnify the bitterness even though its only 45 IBUs. Overall, its an interesting twist, but not enough for a first down...

Flavor is light caramel, nutty, toasted malts, toffee, fading into a mildly bitter, piney, mildly resinous, citrus finish, and a bitter, piney aftertaste. More balanced flavor than I recall from earlier tastings. Soft carbonation, medium-light body, and smooth texture. Lightly dry finish.

Clear amber pour with a small off-white head. Sweet, bready aroma, with light tropical fruit. The flavor is lightly sweet like fruit juice, but not as heavy. Good bitterness balances the sweetness. Nice long finish. Better after a bit of warming. Pleasant and tasty. The fruitiness intensifies. An excellent beer. Interesting blend take on the style.

Pours two fingers of head on a clear straw colored body.
The aroma is lemon and grapefruit, and a little mango.
The taste is grainy sweetness with a dank bitter background. Some tropical fruit sweetness at the end.
The texture is thicker.
Enjoyable.
bottle. Pale copper with small head. Tropical fruit in a maibock. Definitely took me a couple sips to decide, but somehow this works for me. Interesting flavors.
Growler. This is a nice simple bock with higher than average hopping. Nice for the price.

This gold beer has a sweet aroma. A spicy sweet flavor which is light and refreshing.

12 ounce can. Pours a dark gold with one inch beige head. Taste is of fruit, malt, caramel, pine, resin and grass. Similar aroma. Has a medium body with a slight fruity and dry finish. Easy to drink and enjoyable. Would have again.

Can - big foamy head, dark copper color, pretty balanced aroma and flavor, sweet malt, mildly fruity hops, expected more "tropical" flavor but still pretty good overall

Taste had similar qualities to the nose, but was better. Got rye malts, scotch, iced tea, caramel, toffee, mango, papaya, light Tropical Punch Bubble Yum, sour caramel apple, melon, passion fruit and boozy malts. (Taste - 3.88)

Medium body. Creamy texture. Average carbonation. Long, boozy, warming finish. (Feel - 3.88)

This beer really grew on me. Tasty, but a tad boozy at times. Would have it again for sure. (Overall - 3.88)

3.82 86 B+

Poured from can to glass. Copper hue with creamy tan head that settled. Aroma is bread, caramel, clove, toffee, slight sulphur. Mouthfeel is great with a medium body and crisp carbonation. Taste is sweet with a spicy hop bitterness following and faint sulphur in the finish. Overall this is a very enjoyable brew.
Draft. Swore I rated this. Had it at Binnys LP a month ago maybe. It is nto super tropical, sweet and not very lagery,

Can: this beer was bad ass! Beer poured red orange. A lot of fruity aroma which is kind of against the main bock style but however I enjoyed it thoroughly. Beer had guava passion fruit citrus note. Beer had a really nice flavor not to malty just right.
Can: Poured a clear orange with off white head. Aroma is fruity, veggie yams, and malts. Taste is passion fruit, tobacco leaf, and bitter finish.

Comes out of tap hazy dark, coppery Amber with buff head. Strong aroma is fruity, pear and apple with a snippet of cherry; hoppy amid malty notes appear on the background. Fruity flavor has malty, hoppy, and subtle caramel notes singing backup. Smooth texture is firm and quite fizzy. Go yonder for this Bock!

This is a really well crafted beer. Tons of fruity flavors like guava and passion fruit. Totally tropical and unlike anything else I've had.

First thing I notice is a volatile mild sweet candy aroma once the can is popped. Then there is this clear bock looking thing in the glass. Strong initial flavors great my lager lovin tongue. A big beer that departs somewhat from the expected roads of the bock.

text: Can, as pictured. Pours a reddish clear color. Does have a little bit of citrus feel to it, maybe some orange peel. Not too heavy though. Easy drinker, light, mostly malty sweetness.
Beautiful amber color with a big beige head. Sweet caramel aroma with a touch of alcohol. Sweet flavor, very light hop bitterness. Velvety mouthfeel. Real smooth. Very nice beer.

Where and how:  GG , can 355ml.
Aroma grainy, malty with slight alcohol dryness to it. Mild touch of soft toffee.
 Appearance :

Palate :  full bodied, well rounded, soft , oily finish.
Taste: solid malt body. Nice softer texture, nice bock roundness to it. Gentle yet noticeable tropical feel to it. 
 Other notes  size moving into traditional double bock territory but you wont feel it. Great solid traditional feel with gentle modern twist to it.
Unique flavor. Very smooth low hops velvety mouth feel with fruity taste. I would say in a category of its own.

[Bottle (12oz)] Pours a deep golden-orange with a large long-lasting frothy off-white head. Aroma of caramel malt, toffee, nuts and a good amount of hops. Flavour of bready caramel malt, toffee, hops, nuts and a moderate bitter finish. Alcohol is totally hidden. Medium bodied. Quite good for the style.

Draught at Elizabeth Station, BellinghamDark brown color, almost black. Chocolate and roasted malt aroma. Good body, bold chocolate flavor with some roasted malt And roasted nuts. Correct bitterness.Warming comforting beer, very good.

I had this at Global Brew. Pours a orangish amber with a off white head. Taste caramel, malt, hoppy, earthy. I thought this was good. I could drink this again.

Overall a pretty tasty brew. Not really catching much of the bock style other that it is pretty smooth.
Clear copper with off white head. Aroma is malt and hops. Taste is overly sweet. Good not great.

On tap at Global brew. Pours a clear orange/amber with an off white head. Cotton candy aroma. Taste is sweet caramel malt, cloying candy and hop bitterness. Almost like a "quality" malt liquor. If such a thing exists.

Location/Date:Can on August 22nd, 2014.
Appearance: Pours a clear maroon.
Aroma: Aroma of light fruit.
Taste:Tropical fruit, lightly malty..
Palate:Light medium body.
Summary: Really enjoyable.

Meh. A typical bock. Take this rating for what its worth because Im not a fan of the style. Aroma was heavy malt with some mango and melon. Pour was a deep dark brown with a thin tan film for a head. Taste was way too sweet. Toasted bread, sweet malt and melon notes. Sticky wet finish with mild carbonation.

text: Draft pint at Fishale. I like it because it didnt have the raw alcohol punch of most maibocks. Nice hop notes, a hint of yeast and a little sweetness. Pleasant.

Pours clear and amber with a foamy white head. Aroma of wood, earth, caramel, and other sweet malts. Taste of caramel, wood, earth, spice, and some background fruit hops. Light to medium body, lively carb, and smooth mouthfeel.
16 oz draft pours clear amber with a off white head. Aroma of caramel, grass, toffee and fruit. Taste is caramel, fruit and some citrus.

12 oz. bottle from one of the Beer Camp packs from Dutchs. Pours a clear, deep reddish amber with a big off-white head, rocky, that leaves lace in the glass and settles unevenly. Aroma of cedar, grass, caramel and toasted malts, tea, some fruits, and a bit of peppery spice. Flavor of caramel, tea, cedar, grass, pepper, and some tropical fruits. Light-medium bodied, with a sweet, spicy mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Really good, interesting beer.

Had on tap at The Grill Next after finishing up an intensive cave exploring tour we booked in Salem. $7.00 for the full pint. Pours a crimson-tinted reddish dark brown with which a foamy, off-white ringed head half a finger in length stood. Aromas of DME, acorns, autumnal leaves, mint, brown malt, Mandarin orange zest, black limes, muscat grape must, caramelized onions, and kindling. Tastes the same with the addition of cedar, white sage, Bible paper, and organic ketchup. Enthralling, yet had been a tad too earthy for my liking. After awhile, it tasted as if I had irrationally poured a Bock onto a tree, and furiously lapped it up with my tongue; so, essentially - strong German lager+bark.

Box was packaged on June 19, 2014.
This was poured into a pilsener.
The appearance was a bronzed amber color with a semi-thick rocky two and a half finger white to off white head. Theres a decent amount of semi-bubbly and somewhat foamy lacing.
The smell started off with a light toasted caramel note and then had a graceful amount of tropical fruits backing it up nicely.
The taste had more of a combination of the tropical fruits and toasty caramel malts coming through fairly sweet.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a sharp carbonation running about it. Theres nothing graceful about how this one rolls across my tongue as theres a decent sharp fruitiness there.
Overall, pretty good maibock Im thinking I could have again.

Tasted from can. Pours a clear copper color with light tan head. Aroma is citrus fruit and some caramel. Taste is moderate to heavy sweetness and mild bitterness. You do get a bunch of tropical fruit flavors in the taste with a bunch of bready, toffee and caramel. Pretty good tasting maibock. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Orange-copper color. Mango and citrus along with a wallop bready sweet malts. Big malts and fruitiness. Fairly sweet and caramel-ly throughout. Didnt go for it at first, but I mellowed into it. Strange, but nice.

Can, shared by me... in my dining room... just now.
Pours an orange color with a small to medium sized head and some spotty lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is bright with a bit of maltiness, some pineapple and some honey. Its a little bready and a touch sweet smelling, but well balanced.

The flavor is pretty indicative of Maibock really, its malty with a light booziness and a mild herbal hop character. The beer is manageably sweet with some honey flavor. The fruitiness is nice but basically mild. 

A fun take on the style.

The aroma is sweet citrus, peach, light caramel, bread. The appearance is dep amber, white head. The flavor is caramel, noble hop spicy. The finish is spicy, sweet, citrusy. Medium in body. Starts out as something different, turns into a normal maibock. Ok overall.

Can. Pours mostly clear copper with thin, fizzy off-white head. Aroma is mango, pineapple, spicy hops, light caramel, and faint grapes. Flavor is dry malts, spicy hop bitterness, light citrus and tropical fruit esters, and faint caramel sweetness. Medium body and carbonation.

From a can. Pours clear bright copper with a fizzy white head. Tastes nutty, like straw, toasted malt, light hop bitterness, light citrus. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like sweet toasted malt, floral, light citrus, light nuttyness.

Very good shiny copper pour w/ a beige head that leaves lacing. Aroma is fruity & sweet w/ some caramel. The taste is crisp & well balanced. Very nice mix of fruit & malt flavor. It hides the nearly 8% abv very well! Very nice overall!

9/13/14. On tap at Kickbacks. Clear amber pour with a small khaki head. Sweet, bready aroma, the fruitiness definitely popping through. The flavor is a bit sweet as well, fruity for sure, surprised at how much the tropical aspect pops. Grew on me as I sipped. Not bad.

Can from mdg164, thanks Marc! Pours brandy colored with almost no head. Caramel, berries and some tangy spices. Additional flavor - dare I say cigar? Much sweeter than typical for style. Almost cloying by the end. 13.6

Cigar city brought the tropics too beer camp. I love cigar city, so this was quite a nice surprise to find all the way up north in new York where we typically cant find their beers. Definitely had hints of mango and citrus through out.
Aromas of tropical fruit, malts, and some hops. Light off white head and mid orange body. Sweet malt flavors some minor tart fruit and very light hops. Crisp and smooth on the palate.

12 oz bottle from Biggie Liquors. Amber and clear appearance with active carbonation and sticky lacing. Malty and fruity with tropical notes, light caramel/toffee and a touch of alcohol in the nose. Similar flavor, with a medium plus body and a creamy mouth feel. Decent.

Deep brown amber. Lots of passion fruit, maybe some overripe fruit rinds on nose. Very sweet with notes of ruby grapefruit, maraschino cherries, pineapples - kind of like fruit cocktail. The bock malts are certainly there, but play a supporting role. The slight toasted malts keep the fruit from becoming too overpowering. Medium mouthfeel with low carbonation. Smooth finish.

Pours hazy copper brown with a medium beige head, good retention, very fine lacing. Very floral aroma with notes of passion fruit, toast, and grass. Medium body, velvety smooth. Medium sweet, a hint of grapefruit, medium bitter finish with a lingering light fruity bitter flavor. A delicious hoppy treat.

On tap at Brixx Pizza. Brownish color pour with a thick off white head. Malty, somewhat fruity nose - lively carbonation. Easy to drink, not too thick, fairly light mouthfeel. Malty and rich, not too many hops. Good beer
Interesting fruity heller. A bit too gassy up front, but neat tropical fruit notes. Even the hops seem more tropical less piney.

My first pick from the box and a winner. Pours a red orange with a hint of brown. Some carbonation. Aroma of tropical fruits, dark malts and chocolate. Taste was of chocolate malts, tropical fruits and as it warmed dark malts and bread crust came through with a hint of alcohol. Some sweetness and a hint of caramel, medium body. Not characteristic of the style but very good.
Sour smell to it looks like bloody piss, not my style of beer but was apart of the pack so Im not gonna let it go to waste, can see why some people like it
12 oz can. Amber with a decent off-white head. Aroma is of malt, passionfruit, toffee, guava, and light grass. Taste is of toffee, bread, toast, guava, light earthiness, and nuts.

12oz can, Pours a deep copper amber with a off white medium lasting fluffy head. Aroma is grains, caramel malt, fruity notes. 12oz can. Large beige head atop clear amber body. Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, some spicy, light earthy, berry. Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, spicy, some chocolate, guava, light earthy. Sticky light-medium body, light effervescence.

Copper color with a medium sized, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of tropical fruits, toasted malts, citrus, caramel, and light alcohol. Taste of caramel, tropical fruits, some brown sugar, raisins, and light alcohol in the finish.

12oz. can. Sweet, malty aroma, some caramel and light brown sugar with touches of tropical fruit, dried leaves and floral hop, one has to really search for these nuances here, though, as the nose is pretty slight. Clear light-medium amber in color with a very fine, sparse, white head. Flavor profile is mildly toasty and malty with touches of brown sugary sweetness here and there, some of the advertised tropical fruit about midpoint, and finishing with a mild to moderate degree of bitterness and faint spice and citrus appearing late. 12 oz can. Poured a mostly clear, perhaps lightly hazed medium-copper color with a small off-white head. Aroma was light toasty malts, sweet malts, caramel notes. Flavor was sweet malts, caramel. Sweet.

Beer camp can. Canned 05/04/14. Pours a crystal clear, bright ruby/orange with a thin, off white head. Aroma has solid tropical fruit notes blended with bread, citrus, caramel, and hints of pine. Slightly syrupy texture with a soft carbonation and a dry finish. Overall an interesting beer. Caramel/bread mixed with softer tropical fruits. Not a bad start to Beer Camp.

Tropical aromas, papaya, peach, pineapple, red berries, subtle caramel. Clear bright red, copper highlights, lasting ring of white. Dry, subtle fruit, sharp hop bitterness as it finishes. Medium bodied.
Some pineapple and fruit aromas, peachy. Very malty, caramel, burnt sugar, not fruity flavors at all. Smooth.

Un éventail de fruits tropicaux très mûrs badigeonné de maltose collant. Le corps est moyen avec un sucre résiduel machable doublé dune finale courte et moyennement sèche. #11. Shared with koleminer20. Aroma is very fruity, mango, peach, pear, slight malt. Appearance is orange, white head. Taste is caramel, some light fruit flavors, and quite malty. Mouthfeel is decent, a little light but the flavor hangs. Overall, its delightful.

Pours clear amber with white head. Aroma is sweet caramel malt with fruity notes. Smooth mouthfeel. Sweet caramel malt start with papaya and pineapple finish.
Nice blend of malts in this collaboration beer. Amber body. A tad sweet for my liking. Honey, and tropical fruits are most prevalent. Not bad within the maibock designation.

Clear coppery red with a dense tan head. Aroma is very fruity, with guava seeming most prominent. Taste is very malty, with a bit of caramelized astringency, and mild solventy alcohol notes into the finish.

12oz bottle. 2014 Beer Camp. Pours dark amber with a white head. Tropical fruit, caramel, toffee, with a hop kick to it. I liked this more than I expected to.

Can: Poured a deep amber color bock with a medium size foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of caramel malt and fruity ester and tropical fruit notes is singular. Poured from the can into a shaker glass. Clear dark amber with a tan head. Aroma is mild but has some light malt and some tropical fruit. Flavor has some sweet maltiness, but I'm not picking up much in the way of fruit. Balanced by some peppery hop character and prickly carbonation. Medium bodied. I'm not big on fruity beers so I actually liked this better than I expected.
clear,amber color; floral, tropical fruit aroma with bready malt notes; a nice, smooth, well balanced beer; bready malt with light caramel notes balanced with hoppy, tropical fruit notes

Can to a dimpled mug. Pours a copper amber color with an offwhite head that remains well. Can pick up some of the floral notes on the nose, and the flavor strong with sweet malt, and good fruit notes as well as hop flavors.
Draft at Churchkey. Clear amber color, medium white head. Aroma of mango, guava. Taste is sweet caramel and tropical fruit. Much more fruity than your average bock.

Can. Dark amber/bronze, quite still, a thin but robust head. If you inhale quite hard, you might get a whiff of tropical fruit, but otherwise this presents itself like a standard American amber ale. Once physically on the palate, the tropical fruit, pineapple, and just a hint of that cedar. Nice. (#5645, 8/26/2014)

Sierra Nevada / Cigar City Beer Camp Yonder Bock is a real treat from the SN Beer Camp series. Fruity hop aroma rising from a copper pour with a white fluffy head. Taste is a nice balance of tropical fruit flavors and hop floral with a nice malt backing. Finish is clean. Nice job CCB and SN!

Can. Pours a clear copper body under a fizzy off-white head that had decent retention due to the vigorous carbonation. A bit of light alcohol in there as well. It tastes very sweet with some tropical fruit, light fruity hops, some honey like pale maltiness, minimal hops on the back end. A bit warming on the finish, medium bodied, a little too active in the carbonation department for me. Meh, not all that big of a fan of this one.

Draft. Pours red-brown with a thin frothy head that lingers. Sweet aroma that doesn't play into the beer. Nutty flavors of a brown ale with a nice hop back bone.

Dark honey colored beer, creamy orangey white head dissipates soon. Aroma malt, yeast, bread, raisin, faint citrus. Taste is light malt, nutty lager, slightly bitter finish. Appearance is a clear light-copper color with a moderate white head. Aroma is tropical fruits, like mango, around some light caramel malts. Not real strong, but nice.Taste follows the nose. Good beer.

4oz pour at Churchkey DC pours a clear amber with a ring of white head. Nose has lots of fruit, apple, pear, mild melon, mild malt, a little yeast. Flavor has sweet apple, mild spice, red pear, orange, crackery too, mild perfume. Finishes fruity, but relatively clean.

Can courtesy of GT2. Pours deep amber with a frothy and fizzy brownish offwhite head that leaves a small trace on the glass while dissipating. Can. Tropical fruit aroma including mango and other fruit with a touch of caramel malt. Pours amber colored with a thin white head and no lacing. Starts quite smooth with tropical fruit flavors and some caramel. Finishes very smooth as well with the tropical fruit flavors mingling nicely with the hops at the end. Nice take on a bock.
Can. Pours amber with a scant off white head. Aroma is caramel and tropical fruit - mango. Flavor is caramel, earth and a touch of mango. A little mineral and a little grass bitter to the finish.
Amber color pour with aroma of sweet bread and malt. Nice mouth feel with smoothness and a mild after taste of bitter hop.
Amber pour with creamy white head. Aroma is sweet malt with a touch of perfumy hops. Sweet malt with a nice floral hop presence but not a lot of bitter. Good carbonation and smooth.
Clear amber pour with large beige head. Toasted malts in the aroma. Taste of toasted bread, cereal, tropical fruit and light herbal hops.

Amber color with a thin white head. Aroma is slightly sweet, vaguely reminiscent of white wine. Flavor is a bit sweet with a robust malt presence. A tiny bit of bitterness in the finish. Theres a hint of rye bread in the aftertaste.

12oz can, Amber pour, thick head, good lacing. Fruit flavor aroma, taste of fruit (maybe mango, pineapple). Medium body, average co2. A great tasting German style brew.

Can. Pours a clear light orange color with a tall head response. Aroma is dry malts, earthy hops and light spices. Flavor is dry, earthy, clay, and dry hops. Light floral notes with a bitter finish.

Pours clear mahogany into a stem. White head with good retention recedes to coat surface. Dark smoky caramel aromas. Thick with sweet molasses and tobacco upfront turning warm in the lasting bitter earth finish.

Appearance:The body is a darker shade of orange and brown, extremely clear, and very reminiscent of dark sun tea. The head is a creamy slightly off-white fluffy cloud that stays up and coats the glass with spotty white foam drops.


Aroma: I get notes of caramel, some citrus rind, and a little bit of pine. A lot more hop character than I would get from a normal Maibock.


Taste: I get a lot of hop flavors right up front, leaning mostly towards what tastes like grapefruit and a bit of apricot and lots of pine. There is a bit of a bread taste to the beer as well.


Palate: It has a good amount of bitterness with a medium body and it lingers on the palate. It is not a traditional feeling Maibock.


Overall: The beer is good if you are looking something like a strong Pale Ale or a slightly weaker IPA. I wouldnt know it was a bock by tasting it. The can touts claims of tropical fruit, but all I picked up was the standard citrus hop flavors. It is a good beer but it is not synchronous with the packaging, name, or style.
bottle in beer camp box, this one was an odd one. Sweet and really thick, but nothing else. Very odd.
12 oz can. Smells like weird Belgian ale and rancid pineapple. This is a total DPF.

Pours copper with average head. Aroma of mango, guava, caramel, bready malt, sweet candied fruit, honey. Flavor is medium sweet, light bitter on the back end.. more tropical candied fruits & biscuit. Big and sweet, but minimal booze, faint bitter & fruit.

12 oz. can from SoHo Organic Market, Elizabeth City, NC. Brownish-orange pour with a fluffy off-white head. Hop forward aroma of citrus and mango that fades to showcase the sweet toffee and caramel malts. The initial taste is of graham cracker but finishes with some tropical fruit flavors and avoids being too sweet or cloying. This is a well done maibock.

Can shared with Annie, pours dark copper orange with small white head. Aromas of body stank, stale plum, and off Belgian notes along with tons of malt. Flavor is all malt, and similiar to a thin and weak brown. Boozy. We both dumped her after a few sips...not sure how old it was.
12 oz can pours clear orange with a decently foamy head. Sweet tropical fruit aroma. Taste is malty and fruity. Hints of pineapple and mango. Not bad.
Pours a clear copper color. Little to no head. No lacing. Aroma is rich, malty and caramel. Malty, caramel flavor.

On tap. Very drinkable beer. Aroma mostly of bready malts but a hint of tropical fruit is detectable. Same on the palate mostly malty with just a hint of fruit. Very balanced, the hops are definitely kept in check and the hops, from what I can detect seem to be the tradition variety.

Canned 14MAY14

Pours a golden beer with a solid, fine light cream sheet. Smells of banana, caramel malts, some alcohol, a bit of pineapple. Flavor is malts, some caramel, a little orange juice, some pineapple juice - meh. Medium bodied with low carb and a nice finish. Overall pretty indifferent.

With Z, pours a clear tea colored head with a tan fluffy head. Nose is sweet caramel and toffee. Taste is sweet with buttery caramel notes like most Bocks, but has more of a hoppy and spicy take. Finishes on the same tasting notes, a very drinkable Bock. Quaff Score

Can, beer camp box. Pours a clear copper with an off white head and aroma of tropical fruits, hops, and bready malt. Taste is of malt, caramel, and bread notes throughout with tropical fruits, pine, and hops into the slight bitter, malty finish.
Drinkable, with some of the heller bock malt. Some noble hops. Light caramel, orange pour. Tap at Churchkey.

Clear amber with a small white head and moderate lace. Aromas of toffee, cereal, raisins, molasses/maple syrup and tropical fruit, but you have to be looking for it. Malt sweetness accompanied by the tropical fruit that is a bit more pronounced than it was on the nose. Medium body, smooth mouthfeel, gently carbonated and a lingering caramel sweetness.

Can pours clear medium amber color. Creamy,pillowy off white head,lingers leaving spots of lace. Aromas of toffee,bread,raisins,molasses,alcohol and a wisp of mango and papaya. Huge taste of malt,bread,honey,dates,citrus and a hint of mango. Medium body,average carbonation, smooth mouthfeel,dry slightly bitter finish. This beer has very intriguing flavors. I cant figure out the tropical fruit flavors,although they sure work well with the fantastic malt backbone. A highly drinkable and pleasant beer for sure. One of the better brews from the beer camp 12er.

12oz can. Sierra Nevada Yonder Bock.  Brilliant amber color with ivory sheen. Nice mango, pineapple, tropical fruit, Hawaiian bread aromas. Medium body with average co2. Bready caramel sweet base brew with tropical fruits, and a mango, pineapple bitter sweetness----pretty tasty.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: In Los Altos. Pours a clear amber-orange with minimal head. Malt is moderate but a little lacking. Not much exciting here as flavor is also restrained malt.
Aroma is strong malt, taste is awesome balance of malt and tropical fruit. Very strong and smooth.
Pours a beautiful clear autumn amber. What a great combo of maibock character with the tropical fruits. Really like this. A nice break on official move in day in AZ.

Took a few minutes for this to open up, but once it did I really enjoyed it. As the description states its a rather full bodied blend of malt and tropical fruit. Bitter and sweet in abundance and very well balanced
Deep copper with thin white head. Sweet aroma of malt. Flavor nice carmel and sweetness from residual sugar. Lingers with a light sweetness to finish. Pretty nice beer.

12oz can from Spirits Brick. Poured a nice looking clear syrupy sun burnt orange with an average sized slightly foamy off white head. Aroma is earthy, dry sugar sweetness, touch of moasses, nut shell, tea leaves, sweet bread. Medium to fuller bodied, average to softer carbonation. Flavor is just slightly better then the aroma. Good stuff.

12 ounce can

A great entry in the Beer Camp pack, this tropical bock has hallmarks of Cigar Citys distinctive style. Of all the offerings in the package this is perhaps the one that I wish could be released on its own. I am sure six packs would fly off the shelves.

Aroma / Appearance - A creamy caramel hue is the tint of cream soda. A fresh vanilla head adds pleasant contrast. Mangoes, malt, and definitive tropical aspects shine in the air. Honey and graham crackers add more depth. Like a slice of fresh pie it makes the whole room sweeter.

Flavor / Palate - Mango, peach, and bright citrus prepare the senses for a tropical beach invasion. Creamy malt driven sips carry strongly towards a dry finish of candy and malts. Refreshing and easy to drink, this is definitely among the best the Beer Camp box has offered so far.
Really nice tropical fruit flavors, easily the best aroma of any of these beer camp beers. It has a nice malt backbone too, with a slight hop bite near the end.

12 oz can poured into a Spiegelau tulip. Canned either 5/4/14 or 6/4/14. Golden brown to amber with two fingers of off-white head. Aromas of tropical fruit, stone fruit, light spice. Tastes of tropical fruit, sweet malt, caramel, spices. Medium-light body with a dry finish. Medium carbonation.

Can shared by Mr Barleywine, Thanks Mike! 
tropical fruity aroma and flavor caramel toffee maltiness medium golden color. A bit fruity, the lesser of the two bocks.

Looks like a perfect german lager with a clear deep orange body and a huge sandy head. Subdued aromas despite the experimental hops advertised on the can, mostly malt. Flavor is fairly similar, but with some tired fruit and herbs in the background layered on top of alcohol. Thick and smooth mouthfeel that leaves stickiness on the lips. This is fine for a beer you might find at your local brewpub, but doesnt really feel tropical to me.

Can pour - orangey amber with a modest white head that has some longevity. Aroma is malty with the slightest hint of citrus in the background - expected a bit more I guess, but its still an interesting touch. Splash of caramel on the nose for good measure. Flavor is malt-forward, some biscuit, tropical hop notes here and there add some depth and bitterness. Palate is nice - easy drinker, good carbonation, etc... Enjoyed this one, but it currently ranks #2 (out of 2) in the Beer Camp 12-pack!

Poured from can into short juice glass (for effect). Amber/ copper color with thin fizzy white head that leaves quickly with no lacing. Smell is mostly grainy/ cereal with some fruity hops. Taste is bready/ yeasty with a little citrusy hops mixed in. Palate is smooth. I actually really like this one. Unassuming and very well balanced, nice drinker.

12oz can 8/13/14 (Beer Camp 12pk)-44° in Mug-44° in Mug-Pours a light amber with a big off white head. Aroma of citrus, hops, and malt. Taste of the same with some caramel and toffee. This medium bodied brew is well balanced and easy drinking.

12oz can pours a reddish Amber color with a medium tan head that leaves light lacing. Smells of tropical hops, caramel, toffee and dark fruit. Tastes of the same things. Mouthfeel thin but silky with decent carbonation. Interesting beer for the style. A lot of different flavors come out as it warms. First beer Ive tried in this years beer camp pack. Its a unique good one. Looking forward to the rest of this pack.
Tap at butcher and the boar. Hint of cigar in the nose. Dry flavor initially that had lager notes but subtle, fruity aspects creep in on 3rd sip. Not overly spectacular but malt heads would dig it.

As of late I can not find the time to take tasting notes of each beer I sample. I would like to track and record my thoughts of each so I will just use the simple scoring rubric until more time is available.

Dark copper to red-heavy amber pour with a sorta chunky two finger off white head. Aroma is caramel, toast, cooked pineapple, and some creamy and stone fruit notes. It smells very much like a pineapple upside-down cake. Flavor is sweet malt, more toffee than caramel up front, then some bready notes, caramel, citrus, cooked pineapple, light spiciness, light oily grain, light vegetal notes and a light sweet potato note to the finish. medium body, slick, kinda goopy feel until the dry, slightly astringent finish. Good stuff overall, doesnt quite come together for me.

Poured from can into glass stein a red orange deep amber. Plenty of fading head and lace a slight off white color. Med body and co2. Aroma is caramel and toffee, taste is malty, with hay and grass notes. I got little of the tropical fruit mostly in the late finish. It sips sweet and finishes a bit bitter. Very nice I would get this again if it was a regular offering.
Can. Deeper gold pour, small white head, minimal retention/lace. Aroma of grassy, tropical hop, caramel, toffee. Taste is lightly bitter, sweet, caramel, biscuit. Palate is soft, slick, sweet finish.
This poured a lighter brown color with a white head. Aroma was of toasted malt, tobacco, and dark fruits. Flavor was tropical and dark fruit, toast, and tobacco, very strange but unique.

The sourdough, tin can, golden raisin notes of the style are prominent in the nose with the framing of tropical, misty hop notes. The lager character is still foremost and the stylistic integrity is there.

The flavor similarly is closely adherent with notes of carrot like sweetness with angel food and raw barley grist, while it is still good and clean. Little bursts of guava and pineapple hops lend some complimentary acidity; no emergent bitterness.

Medium, effervescent palate; it can seem a bit heavy at times, but it finishes crisp and clear. This is one of the most focused, well made beers in the set.

12 oz can shared by csbosox. 06/04/14 stamped on the bottle. The pour is a clear golden, copper, orange with a ½ inch white head. The aroma is tropical fruit and straw malt. The taste is the tropical guava pineapple hop notes along with cracker straw grassy malt. Nice balance with clean flavors. The palate is medium bodied with a slick mouthfeel and the fruit finish lingers a bit. Thanks for sharing all of these beers with me Chris.

Part of the Beer Camp series, this pours a deep amber into the glass with a fully diminished head that leaves trace lacing. The heavy nose is of fruity eaters and light caramel. Flavors are of tropical citrus and melons, focusing on pineapple and kiwi, caramel notes, and finishing with a curt hop finish that cleanses the palate. Nice take on the maibock! Again, a lager that isn't easy to differentiate itself from the pack, but this has done a wonderful job!! Very reminiscent of all-inclusive South American resort aperitifs. Complex and substantive, the round, medium body is smooth going down, and reminiscent of island offerings. Very nice take on the style!!

12 oz can into a can glass. Pours a dark clear amber with a lazy head. Nose is caramel malts, faded hops and some muted tropical fruits. Taste is caramel, bread, and faded fruits. Its...good, but really falls flat for being old. Luckily it still retains enough fruitiness to not come off as boring.
Pours a clear golden with a medium white head. Aroma of sweet tropical fruits and hops with malt. Taste of smooth sweet coconut with tropical fruits and hops. Pretty tasty!

Can from the mix pack. Pours a beautiful red orange color, slight haze , with a big creamy off white head. Aroma of sweet malts, Brady, some fruits, sweet sugars. Flavor is nice bready malts, lots of sweetness, some tropical fruit notes, and a crisp finish that keeps this far from too sweet. Medium plus body, very smooth and silky, with medium carbonation. This was pretty nice.

Pours a slightly hazy amber with an off-white head and lacing. It has a mild malt aroma with lots of bright tropical fruit and a flavor that is malt-forward with a fruit backbone leading to a sweet finish.

Tropical aroma. Flavors of pineapple, mango, gauva balanced by caramel and general malts. Rich, grainy bread, oranges and floral hops round it out. This is well crafted, not too sweet, not too bitter. Medium bodied and nice, sharp carbonation.
Beer camp #4. Can pour. Pours amber with a malty aroma. Big, soda like head. Sweet, malty flavors. Some fruit. Long sugary finish. Good beer overall, but nothing outstanding.

Amber pour with a white head. The aroma is very malty with some unidentifiable fruit notes also coming through. The flavor is very sweet and very fruity. I get a lot of brown sugar as well as some toffee and caramel. There is also some orange and mango notes. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

A nice bock, but not quite as interesting as expected. Pours a very nice clear dark amber. Smells of cranberries and a bit of marzipan. Tate is complex but a bit muddy. Starts with some dry hoppiness, and ends sweet. Had in the can.

Pours a crystal clear amber-golden with a sudsy, pull candy colored head. Faint nose of toasty sweetness. Medium to full body with some carbonation burn. Sorghum and biscuit baked a little long in the flavors.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2014 Can: Cloudy copper body with amber edges, the eggshell head foams up nicely, leaving a nice sheet of chunky lacing behind as it slowly recedes. Aroma is mostly bock. Toasted caramel, some nuttiness, CaraMunich malt sweetness. Theres only a touch of lightly citric, American hops, but its very faint. Thats the only real "fruit" essence on the nose, & I would not consider it tropical. Taste has a slight tropical essence... I guess. But it might be mostly the power of suggestion. Mostly some dry caramel malt, toffee, nuts, toasted bread, hint of earthy & bitter hops. Some sips actually have a fairly pungent, botanical bitter bite to them. A light vague fruitiness, but again, it doesnt make me think "tropical". It doesnt blend very well with the bock itself, either. Some finishing perfume notes. Far from undrinkable, but I wasnt a huge fan of this one.

2014 Beer Camp Across America Tour, mixed 12pk. 12oz can. Clear, copper color. Smells of toasted malts. Wooded hops. Tastes of sweet Bock malts, lights bitterness. Finishes with notes of tropical fruits from hops. (4144)
Can. Pours reddish amber cream white head. Nose/taste of tropical fruit, honey malt, sugary spice, old mango and pineapple juice. Lighter medium body.

From the can - perhaps some tropical notes in the aroma but hard to tell - mostly bread sweet malt with sugary spice and raisin. Taste is raisin, sugar spice, sweet malt, and light bitterness. Lightly coating mouthfeel. I did not get much of the tropical angle but it was a nice enough beer regardless.

P: Medium body with high carbonation - finish is medium.
O: Interesting spin on a bock - the tropical fruit flavors are nice - nice, full malt backbone, rich - hops are a bit high and the tannic quality isnt great.
Under attenuated very sweet bock with some moderate tropical fruit hops. Not bad but I wouldn't drink again.
Fruity hop notes of things like pineapple and mango on a semisweet crackery malt body, really tasty, would love if this were fresher, still great even with the two months or so of age.

Poured from can into a pint glass
 Appearance  The beer pours a clear orange amber color with a thick two finger white head that has fantastic retention. The head slowly fades over a long time to leave a fantastic level of foamy lacing on the sides of the glass.
 Smell  The nose of the beer heavy of a tropical fruit smell with lots of mango and pineapple as well as a decent sum of tangerine and some apricot. Along with the fruity smells comes a decent bready and doughty aroma as well as a little bit of a grainy and floral/herbal hop aroma.
 Taste  The taste begins with a bready taste mixed with some caramel and fruity sweetness of a tropical nature. Mango and tangerine are the heaviest upfront and grow stronger and stronger as the taste moves onto the end getting rather strong at the finish of the taste. Along with the increase in the sweet fruity flavors, some small amounts of hop come to the tongue, with them being mainly of a floral and herbal nature. Some flavors of pear and pineapple come at the very end, leaving a rather bready and fruity sweet flavor to linger on the tongue.
 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the thicker and creamier side with a carbonation level that is on the average side. For the combination of sweet and bready flavors of the brew the thickness and carbonation are quite nice as they support the sweet and bready nicely all while keeping it rather drinkable and refreshing of the fruity flavors.
 Overall  At 7.7 % abv the alcohol taste is almost non-existent and the flavor exhibits big fruity and bready flavors. A very drinkable Maibock with a nice flavor profile. Even while on the slightly sweeter side , this was a rather good drinker.

12 ounce can into lager glass, canned on 6/4/2014. Pours slightly hazy orange/copper color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty foamy lacing clings down on the glass. Aromas of caramel, toast, brown bread, pineapple, mango, guava, orange zest, pear, apple, herbal, floral, and yeast earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark/bready malt, tropical/floral hops, and yeast ester notes; with good strength. Taste of caramel, toast, brown bread, pineapple, guava, mango, orange zest, pear, apple, herbal, floral, light pepper, and yeast eathiness. Fair amount of earthy/peppery bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, toast, brown bread, pineapple, guava, mango, orange zest, pear, apple, herbal, floral, light pepper, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice complexity and robustness of dark/bready malt, tropical/floral hops, yeast ester flavors; with a great malt/hop balance with zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light carbonation and medium bodied; with a very smooth, crisp, and lightly slick/bready mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a damn nice hoppy maibock style. All around great robustness, complexity, and balance of dark/bready malt, tropical hops, and yeast ester flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink for the ABV. A very enjoyable offering.
